awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evaluating Retreat in the Amundsen Sea Embayment: Assessing Controlling Processes, Uncertainties, and Projections

por.por_cntn:
Accurate reconstructions and predictions of glacier movement on timescales of human interest require a better understanding of available observations and the ability to model the key processes that govern ice flow. Many of these processes are interconnected, are loosely constrained by data, and involve not only the ice, but also the atmosphere, ocean, and solid Earth, making this a challenging endeavor that is essential for Earth-system modeling and the resulting climate and sea-level forecasts that are provided to policymakers worldwide. Based on the amount of ice present in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet and its ability to flow and/or melt into the ocean, its complete collapse would result in a global sea-level rise of 3.3 to 5 meters, making its stability and rate of change scientific questions of global societal significance.

Recent observations of the Amundsen Sea Embayment (ASE) of West Antarctica indicate that it is experiencing faster mass loss than any other region of the continent. At present, the long-term stability of this embayment is unknown, with both theory and observations suggesting that collapse is possible. This study focused on this critical region as well as processes governing changes in outlet glacier flow. It led to improved physical understanding and future data-collection strategies. The project included five different ice-flow models and six investigators (three early career, one underrepresented) across four institutions, three graduate students (one underrepresented), and two undergraduates (one double minority). At UCI alone, this project helped partially fund one graduate student, and led to 3 peer-reviewed publications that focused on modeling ice-ocean interactions with a coupled numerical model, improving our knowledge of the bathymetry under floating ice shelves, and deriving a new parameterization of ocean-induced melt for implementation in stand alone ice sheet models.

Almost all glaciers and ice streams flow along valleys, but Thwaites Glacier (TG) is like some historical ice flow in going across the dominant topography. We addressed the controlling processes associated with this flow across topography through geophysical and numerical modeling studies, which together indicate that remotely constraining basal properties and their origin is both doable and critical to future projections of ice flow in the ASE.

In the event that TG loses its resistance to rapid flow, whether by removal of its remaining floating ice shelf (e.g., through ocean melting or calving icebergs) which provides drag particularly on its eastern side and/or by widening of the fast-flowing inland regions (e.g., through basal lubrication), the overall flow response depends strongly on the basal properties and tends towards collapse of Thwaites within a few centuries, with the rate determined by the poorly-constrained bed conditions as well as the timing of the processes that ultimately reduce the flow resistance.

Through observations and modeling, unfortunately we found that a period of several years of ocean cooling in Pine Island Bay only temporarily slowed the flow of Pine Island Glacier?s floating ice shelf and did little to slow its retreat.

As far as potential future forcings, perhaps the fastest way to evacuate ice from the ASE is through ice-cliff failure. We determined that sufficiently tall ice cliffs will ultimately fail by slumping (much like on hillslopes) followed by buoyancy-driven calving. The processes associated with cliff failure are active now for the highest cliffs in the warmer Greenland and Antarctic Peninsula Ice Sheets, and could occur much faster if TG loses its ice shelf and retreats into the deep interior basins, generating cliffs taller than any now observed.

One possible way to slow down this catastrophic failure mode is to clog the outlet to the open ocean by mixing sea ice with icebergs. A continuum model of this so-called ice m?lange was developed and applied to drastic retreat episodes of the Antarctic Ice Sheet. The main conclusion is that m?lange in Antarctica does little to slow retreat and ice collapse, due to the much wider basins in Antarctica compared to the much narrower Greenland fjords.

We also presented different statistical techniques that can be used to assess ice-flow response to external forcings. In one study, we learned that data collection focused on down-glacier conditions is extremely valuable in predicting overall outlet glacier flow, but that observations of time-varying events elsewhere is also critical for improving our knowledge of the basal conditions that control the rate and extent of the outlet glacier evolution.

Finally, geologic setting also impacts ice flow through heat flowing up from the rocks below. Past fluctuations of the Greenland ice sheet and its ongoing shrinkage have changed stresses in the underlying rocks, which we found may have aided in bringing melted rock upward, thereby increasing heat flow to the base of the ice. With loading and unloading in West Antarctica, the heat flow in the ASE may have also been impacted in ways that help promote wide-spread lubrication at the ice-bed interface.
